Text

THE other day , in looking over [my]0-i papers , [I]0-i found in [my]0-i desk the following copy of a letter , sent by [me]0-i a year since to [an old school acquaintance]276-an old school acquaintance : — “ [DEAR CHARLES]91-dear charles , “[0-i] [I]0-i think when [you]277-you and [I]0-i were at [Eton]1-eton together , [we]278-we were neither of [us]278-we what could be called [popular characters]279-popular characters : [you]277-you were [a sarcastic , observant , shrewd , cold - blooded creature]280-a sarcastic , observant , shrewd , cold - blooded creature ; [my]0-i own portrait [I]0-i will not attempt to draw , but [I]0-i can not recollect that it was a strikingly attractive one — can [you]277-you ? What animal magnetism drew [thee]277-you and [me]0-i together [I]0-i know not ; certainly [I]0-i never experienced anything of the Pylades and Orestes sentiment for [you]277-you , and [I]0-i have reason to believe that [you]277-you , on [your]277-you part , were equally free from all romantic regard to [me]0-i . Still , out of school hours [we]278-we walked and talked continually together ; when the theme of conversation was [[our]278-we companions]281-our companions or [[our]278-we masters]282-our masters [we]278-we understood [each other]283-each other , and when [I]0-i recurred to some sentiment of affection , some vague love of an excellent or beautiful object , whether in animate or inanimate nature , [your]277-you sardonic coldness did not move [me]0-i . [I]0-i felt [myself]0-i superior to that check then as [I]0-i do now . “ It is a long time since [I]0-i wrote to [you]277-you , and a still longer time since [I]0-i saw [you]277-you . Chancing to take up a newspaper of [[your]277-you county]1871-your county the other day , [my]0-i eye fell upon [your]277-you name . [I]0-i began to think of old times ; to run over the events which have transpired since [we]278-we separated ; and [I]0-i sat down and commenced this letter . What [you]277-you have been doing [I]0-i know not ; but [you]277-you shall hear , if [you]277-you choose to listen , how [the world]1872-the world has wagged with [me]0-i . “[0-i] First , after leaving [Eton]1-eton , [I]0-i had an interview with [[my]0-i maternal uncles]284-my maternal uncles , [Lord Tynedale]92-lord tynedale and [the Hon]285-the hon . [John Seacombe]93-john seacombe . [They]284-my maternal uncles asked [me]0-i if [I]0-i would enter [the Church]286-the church , and [[my]0-i uncle]287-my uncle [the nobleman]288-the nobleman offered [me]0-i the living of [Seacombe]94-seacombe , which is in [his]288-the nobleman gift , if [I]0-i would ; then [[my]0-i other uncle]289-my other uncle , [Mr. Seacombe]94-seacombe , hinted that when [I]0-i became [rector of [[Seacombe]94-seacombe - cum - Scaife]3-seacombe - cum - scaife]290-rector of seacombe - cum - scaife , [I]0-i might perhaps be allowed to take , as [mistress of [[my]0-i house]292-my house and head of [[my]0-i parish]293-my parish]291-mistress of my house and head of my parish , [one of [[my]0-i six cousins]295-my six cousins , [[his]288-the nobleman daughters]296-his daughters , all of whom [I]0-i greatly dislike]294-one of my six cousins , his daughters , all of whom i greatly dislike . “ [I]296-his daughters declined both the Church and matrimony . [A good clergyman]1873-a good clergyman is a good thing , but [I]296-his daughters should have made a very bad one . As to [the wife]1874-the wife — oh how like a night - mare is the thought of being bound for life to [one of [[my]296-his daughters cousins]1876-my cousins]1875-one of my cousins ! No doubt [they]1876-my cousins are accomplished and pretty ; but not an accomplishment , not a charm of theirs , touches a chord in [my]296-his daughters bosom . To think of passing the winter evenings by [the parlour fire - side of [Seacombe Rectory]4-seacombe rectory]1877-the parlour fire - side of seacombe rectory alone with [one of [them]1876-my cousins]1878-one of them — for instance , the large and well - modelled statue , [Sarah]95-sarah — no ; [I]296-his daughters should be [a bad husband]1879-a bad husband , under such circumstances , as well as [a bad clergyman]1880-a bad clergyman . “[296-his daughters] When [I]0-i had declined [[my]0-i uncles]297-my uncles ’ offers [they]297-my uncles asked [me]0-i ‘ what [I]0-i intended to do ? ’ [I]0-i said [I]0-i should reflect . [They]297-my uncles reminded [me]0-i that [I]0-i had no fortune , and no expectation of any , and , after a considerable pause , [Lord Tynedale]92-lord tynedale demanded sternly , ‘ Whether [I]0-i had thoughts of following [[my]0-i father]298-my father ’s steps and engaging in trade ? ’ Now , [I]0-i had had no thoughts of the sort . [I]0-i do not think that [my]0-i turn of mind qualifies [me]0-i to make [a good tradesman]299-a good tradesman ; [my]0-i taste , [my]0-i ambition does not lie in that way ; but such was the scorn expressed in [Lord Tynedale]92-lord tynedale ’s countenance as [he]92-lord tynedale pronounced the word trade — such the contemptuous sarcasm of [his]92-lord tynedale tone — that [I]0-i was instantly decided . [[My]0-i father]298-my father was but a name to [me]0-i , yet that name [I]0-i did not like to hear mentioned with a sneer to [my]0-i very face . [I]0-i answered then , with haste and warmth , ‘ [I]0-i can not do better than follow in [[my]0-i father]298-my father ’s steps ; yes , [I]0-i will be [a tradesman]302-a tradesman . ’ [[My]0-i uncles]297-my uncles did not remonstrate ; [they]297-my uncles and [I]0-i parted with mutual disgust . In reviewing this transaction , [I]0-i find that [I]0-i was quite right to shake off the burden of [Tynedale]92-lord tynedale ’s patronage , but [a fool]304-a fool to offer [my]0-i shoulders instantly for the reception of another burden — one which might be more intolerable , and which certainly was yet untried . “ [I]0-i wrote instantly to [Edward]96-edward — [you]96-edward know [Edward]96-edward — [[my]0-i only brother , ten years [my]0-i senior]1881-my only brother , ten years my senior , married to [[a rich mill - owner]1882-a rich mill - owner ’s daughter]1883-a rich mill - owner ’s daughter , and now possessor of the mill and business which was [[my]0-i father]298-my father ’s before [he]298-my father failed . [You]96-edward are aware that [[my]0-i father]298-my father — once reckoned [a Croesus of wealth]1886-a croesus of wealth — became bankrupt a short time previous to [his]298-my father death , and that [[my]0-i mother]1887-my mother lived in destitution for some six months after [him]298-my father , unhelped by [[her]1887-my mother aristocratical brothers]1888-her aristocratical brothers , whom [she]1887-my mother had mortally offended by [her]1887-my mother union with [Crimsworth]96-edward , [the —— shire manufacturer]1889-the —— shire manufacturer . At the end of the six months [she]1887-my mother brought [me]0-i into [the world]1872-the world , and then [herself]1887-my mother left [it]1872-the world without , [I]0-i should think , much regret , as it contained little hope or comfort for [her]1887-my mother . “[0-i] [[[My]0-i father]298-my father ’s relations]306-my father ’s relations took charge of [Edward]96-edward , as [they]306-my father ’s relations did of [me]0-i , till [I]0-i was nine years old . At that period it chanced that the representation of [an important borough]307-an important borough in [our county]308-our county fell vacant ; [Mr. Seacombe]94-seacombe stood for it . [[My]0-i uncle]287-my uncle [Crimsworth]96-edward , [an astute mercantile man]310-an astute mercantile man , took the opportunity of writing a fierce letter to [the candidate]311-the candidate , stating that if [he]287-my uncle and [Lord Tynedale]92-lord tynedale did not consent to do something towards the support of [[their]312-they sister ’s orphan children]313-their sister ’s orphan children , [he]287-my uncle would expose [their]312-they relentless and malignant conduct towards [that sister]314-that sister , and do [his]287-my uncle best to turn the circumstances against [Mr. Seacombe]94-seacombe ’s election . [That gentleman]315-that gentleman and [Lord T.]97-lord t. knew well enough that [the Crimsworths]98-the crimsworths were [an unscrupulous and determined race]316-an unscrupulous and determined race ; [they]312-they knew also that [they]312-they had influence in [the borough of X]317-the borough of x — — ; and , making a virtue of necessity , [they]312-they consented to defray the expenses of [my]0-i education . [I]0-i was sent to [Eton]1-eton , where [I]0-i remained ten years , during which space of time [Edward]96-edward and [I]0-i never met . [He]287-my uncle , when [he]287-my uncle grew up , entered into trade , and pursued [his]287-my uncle calling with such diligence , ability , and success , that now , in [his]287-my uncle thirtieth year , [he]287-my uncle was fast making a fortune . Of this [I]0-i was apprised by the occasional short letters [I]0-i received from [him]287-my uncle , some three or four times a year ; which said letters never concluded without some expression of determined enmity against [the house of [Seacombe]94-seacombe]318-the house of seacombe , and some reproach to [me]0-i for living , as [he]287-my uncle said , on the bounty of [that house]319-that house . At first , while still in boyhood , [I]0-i could not understand why , as [I]0-i had [no parents]320-no parents , [I]0-i should not be indebted to [[my]0-i uncles]297-my uncles [Tynedale]92-lord tynedale and [Seacombe]94-seacombe for [my]0-i education ; but as [I]0-i grew up , and heard by degrees of the persevering hostility , the hatred till death evinced by [them]297-my uncles against [[my]0-i father]298-my father — of the sufferings of [[my]0-i mother]1887-my mother — of all the wrongs , in short , of [[our]324-our house]325-our house — then did [I]0-i conceive shame of the dependence in which [I]0-i lived , and form a resolution no more to take bread from hands which had refused to minister to the necessities of [[my]0-i dying mother]326-my dying mother . It was by these feelings [I]0-i was influenced when [I]0-i refused the Rectory of [Seacombe]94-seacombe , and the union with [one of [[my]0-i patrician cousins]328-my patrician cousins]327-one of my patrician cousins . “ An irreparable breach thus being effected between [[my]0-i uncles]297-my uncles and [myself]0-i , [I]0-i wrote to [Edward]96-edward ; told [him]298-my father what had occurred , and informed [him]298-my father of [my]0-i intention to follow [his]298-my father steps and be [a tradesman]302-a tradesman . [I]0-i asked , moreover , if [he]298-my father could give [me]0-i employment . [His]298-my father answer expressed no approbation of [my]0-i conduct , but [he]298-my father said [I]0-i might come down to — — shire , if [I]0-i liked , and [he]298-my father would ‘ see what could be done in the way of furnishing [me]0-i with work . ’ [I]0-i repressed all — even mental comment on [his]298-my father note — packed [my]0-i trunk and carpet - bag , and started for [the North]1893-the north directly . “[0-i] After two days ’ travelling ( [railroads]329-railroads were not then in existence ) [I]0-i arrived , one wet October afternoon , in [the town of X——.]330-the town of x——. [I]0-i had always understood that [Edward]96-edward lived in [this town]331-this town , but on inquiry [I]0-i found that it was only [[Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth ’s mill and warehouse which were situated in the smoky atmosphere of [Bigben Close]5-bigben close]332-mr. crimsworth ’s mill and warehouse which were situated in the smoky atmosphere of bigben close ; [[his]99-mr. crimsworth residence]333-his residence lay four miles out , in [the country]334-the country . “ It was late in the evening when [I]99-mr. crimsworth alighted at the gates of [the habitation designated to [me]99-mr. crimsworth as [[my]99-mr. crimsworth brother]1895-my brother ’s]1894-the habitation designated to me as my brother ’s . As [I]99-mr. crimsworth advanced up [the avenue]1896-the avenue , [I]99-mr. crimsworth could see through the shades of twilight , and the dark gloomy mists which deepened those shades , that [the house]1897-the house was large , and the grounds surrounding [it]1897-the house sufficiently spacious . [I]99-mr. crimsworth paused a moment on [the lawn]1898-the lawn in front , and leaning [my]99-mr. crimsworth back against a tall tree which rose in the centre , [I]99-mr. crimsworth gazed with interest on [the exterior of [Crimsworth Hall]6-crimsworth hall]1899-the exterior of crimsworth hall . “[99-mr. crimsworth] [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth is rich , ” thought [I]99-mr. crimsworth to [myself]99-mr. crimsworth . ‘ [I]99-mr. crimsworth believed [him]99-mr. crimsworth to be doing well — but [I]99-mr. crimsworth did not know [he]99-mr. crimsworth was master of [a mansion like this]1900-a mansion like this . ’ Cutting short all marvelling ; speculation , conjecture , & c. , [I]99-mr. crimsworth advanced to the front door and rang . [A man - servant]1901-a man - servant opened it — [I]99-mr. crimsworth announced [myself]99-mr. crimsworth — [he]1901-a man - servant relieved [me]99-mr. crimsworth of [my]99-mr. crimsworth wet cloak and carpet - bag , and ushered [me]99-mr. crimsworth into [a room furnished as [a library]1903-a library , where there was a bright fire and candles burning on the table]1902-a room furnished as a library , where there was a bright fire and candles burning on the table ; [he]1901-a man - servant informed [me]99-mr. crimsworth that [[his]1901-a man - servant master]1904-his master was not yet returned from [X]7-x —— market , but that [he]1904-his master would certainly be at [home]1905-home in the course of half an hour . “[99-mr. crimsworth] Being left to [myself]0-i , [I]0-i took the stuffed easy chair , covered with red morocco , which stood by the fireside , and while [my]0-i eyes watched the flames dart from the glowing coals , and the cinders fall at intervals on the hearth , [my]0-i mind busied itself in conjectures concerning the meeting about to take place . Amidst much that was doubtful in the subject of these conjectures , there was one thing tolerably certain — [I]0-i was in no danger of encountering severe disappointment ; from this , the moderation of [my]0-i expectations guaranteed [me]0-i . [I]0-i anticipated no overflowings of fraternal tenderness ; [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth ’s letters had always been such as to prevent the engendering or harbouring of delusions of this sort . Still , as [I]0-i sat awaiting [his]99-mr. crimsworth arrival , [I]0-i felt eager — very eager — [I]0-i can not tell [you]335-you why ; [my]0-i hand , so utterly a stranger to the grasp of a kindred hand , clenched itself to repress the tremor with which impatience would fain have shaken it . “ [I]0-i thought of [[my]0-i uncles]297-my uncles ; and as [I]0-i was engaged in wondering whether [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth ’s indifference would equal the cold disdain [I]0-i had always experienced from [them]297-my uncles , [I]0-i heard [the avenue]1896-the avenue gates open : wheels approached [the house]1897-the house ; [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth was arrived ; and after the lapse of some minutes , and a brief dialogue between [himself]99-mr. crimsworth and [[his]99-mr. crimsworth servant]1909-his servant in [the hall]1910-the hall , [his]99-mr. crimsworth tread drew near the library door — that tread alone announced [the master of [the house]1897-the house]1911-the master of the house . “[0-i] [I]0-i still retained some confused recollection of [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth as [he]99-mr. crimsworth was ten years ago — [a tall , wiry , raw youth]336-a tall , wiry , raw youth ; now , as [I]0-i rose from [my]0-i seat and turned towards [the library]337-the library door , [I]0-i saw [a fine - looking and powerful man]338-a fine - looking and powerful man , [light - complexioned , well - made , and of athletic proportions]339-light - complexioned , well - made , and of athletic proportions ; the first glance made [me]0-i aware of an air of promptitude and sharpness , shown as well in [his]338-a fine - looking and powerful man movements as in [his]338-a fine - looking and powerful man port , [his]338-a fine - looking and powerful man eye , and the general expression of [his]338-a fine - looking and powerful man face . [He]338-a fine - looking and powerful man greeted [me]0-i with brevity , and , in the moment of shaking hands , scanned [me]0-i from head to foot ; [he]338-a fine - looking and powerful man took [his]338-a fine - looking and powerful man seat in the morocco covered arm - chair , and motioned [me]0-i to another seat . “ ‘ [I]338-a fine - looking and powerful man expected [you]0-i would have called at [the counting - house]1913-the counting - house in [the Close]1914-the close , ’ said [he]338-a fine - looking and powerful man ; and [his]338-a fine - looking and powerful man voice , [I]338-a fine - looking and powerful man noticed , had an abrupt accent , probably habitual to [him]338-a fine - looking and powerful man ; [he]338-a fine - looking and powerful man spoke also with a guttural northern tone , which sounded harsh in [my]338-a fine - looking and powerful man ears , accustomed to the silvery utterance of [the South]1915-the south . “[338-a fine - looking and powerful man] ‘ [The landlord of [the inn]341-the inn]340-the landlord of the inn , where [the coach]342-the coach stopped , directed [me]0-i here , ’ said [I.]0-i ‘ [I]0-i doubted at first the accuracy of [his]340-the landlord of the inn information , not being aware that [you]0-i had such [a residence]343-a residence as this . ’ “ ‘ Oh , it is all right ! ’ [he]338-a fine - looking and powerful man replied , ‘ only [I]0-i was kept half an hour behind time , waiting for [you]338-a fine - looking and powerful man — that is all . [I]0-i thought [you]338-a fine - looking and powerful man must be coming by [the eight o’clock coach]1916-the eight o’clock coach . ’ “[0-i] [I]0-i expressed regret that [he]340-the landlord of the inn had had to wait ; [he]340-the landlord of the inn made no answer , but stirred the fire , as if to cover a movement of impatience ; then [he]340-the landlord of the inn scanned [me]0-i again . “ [I]340-the landlord of the inn felt an inward satisfaction that [I]340-the landlord of the inn had not , in the first moment of meeting , betrayed any warmth , any enthusiasm ; that [I]340-the landlord of the inn had saluted [this man]1917-this man with a quiet and steady phlegm . “[340-the landlord of the inn] ‘ Have [you]0-i quite broken with [Tynedale]92-lord tynedale and [Seacombe]94-seacombe ? ’ [he]340-the landlord of the inn asked hastily . “ ‘ [I]340-the landlord of the inn do not think [I]340-the landlord of the inn shall have any further communication with [them]1918-them ; [my]340-the landlord of the inn refusal of [their]1918-them proposals will , [I]340-the landlord of the inn fancy , operate as a barrier against all future intercourse . ’ “[340-the landlord of the inn] ‘ Why , ’ said [he]340-the landlord of the inn , ‘ [I]0-i may as well remind [you]0-i at the very outset of [our]344-our connection , that “ [no man]1919-no man can serve [two masters]1920-two masters . ”[340-the landlord of the inn] Acquaintance with [Lord Tynedale]92-lord tynedale will be incompatible with assistance from [me]0-i . ’ There was a kind of gratuitous menace in [his]340-the landlord of the inn eye as [he]340-the landlord of the inn looked at [me]0-i in finishing this observation . “ Feeling no disposition to reply to [him]340-the landlord of the inn , [I]340-the landlord of the inn contented [myself]340-the landlord of the inn with an inward speculation on the differences which exist in the constitution of [men]1921-men ’s minds . [I]340-the landlord of the inn do not know what inference [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth drew from [my]340-the landlord of the inn silence — whether [he]99-mr. crimsworth considered it a symptom of contumacity or an evidence of [my]340-the landlord of the inn being cowed by [his]99-mr. crimsworth peremptory manner . After a long and hard stare at [me]340-the landlord of the inn , [he]340-the landlord of the inn rose sharply from [his]340-the landlord of the inn seat . “[340-the landlord of the inn] ‘ To - morrow , ’ said [he]340-the landlord of the inn , ‘ [I]0-i shall call [your]0-i attention to some other points ; but now it is supper time , and [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward is probably waiting ; will [you]0-i come ? ’ “ [He]340-the landlord of the inn strode from [the room]1922-the room , and [I]0-i followed . In crossing [the hall]1910-the hall , [I]0-i wondered what [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward might be . ‘ Is [she]96-edward , ’ thought [I]0-i , ‘ as alien to what [I]0-i like as [Tynedale]92-lord tynedale , [Seacombe]94-seacombe , [the Misses Seacombe]100-the misses seacombe — as [the affectionate relative now striding before [me]0-i]1924-the affectionate relative now striding before me ? or is [she]96-edward better than these ? Shall [I]0-i , in conversing with [her]96-edward , feel free to show something of [my]0-i real nature ; or — ’ Further conjectures were arrested by [my]0-i entrance into [the dining - room]1925-the dining - room . “[0-i] A lamp , burning under a shade of ground - glass , showed [a handsome apartment]345-a handsome apartment , wainscoted with oak ; supper was laid on the table ; by the fire - place , standing as if waiting [our]346-our entrance , appeared [a lady]347-a lady ; [she]347-a lady was young , tall , and well shaped ; [her]347-a lady dress was handsome and fashionable : so much [my]0-i first glance sufficed to ascertain . A gay salutation passed between [her]347-a lady and [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth ; [she]347-a lady chid [him]99-mr. crimsworth , half playfully , half poutingly , for being late ; [her]347-a lady voice ( [I]0-i always take voices into the account in judging of character ) was lively — it indicated , [I]0-i thought , good animal spirits . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth soon checked [her]347-a lady animated scolding with a kiss — a kiss that still told of [the bridegroom]348-the bridegroom ( [they]349-they had not yet been married a year ) ; [she]347-a lady took [her]347-a lady seat at the supper - table in first - rate spirits . Perceiving [me]0-i , [she]347-a lady begged [my]0-i pardon for not noticing [me]0-i before , and then shook hands with [me]0-i , as [ladies]350-ladies do when a flow of good - humour disposes [them]350-ladies to be cheerful to all , even the most indifferent of [their]350-ladies acquaintance . It was now further obvious to [me]0-i that [she]347-a lady had a good complexion , and features sufficiently marked but agreeable ; [her]347-a lady hair was red — quite red . [She]347-a lady and [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth talked much , always in a vein of playful contention ; [she]347-a lady was vexed , or pretended to be vexed , that [he]99-mr. crimsworth had that day driven a vicious horse in the gig , and [he]99-mr. crimsworth made light of [her]347-a lady fears . Sometimes [she]347-a lady appealed to [me]0-i . “ ‘ Now , [Mr. William]101-william , is n’t it absurd in [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth to talk so ? [He]99-mr. crimsworth says [he]99-mr. crimsworth will drive [Jack]102-jack , and no other horse , and [the brute]1926-the brute has thrown [him]99-mr. crimsworth twice already . “[347-a lady] [She]347-a lady spoke with a kind of lisp , not disagreeable , but childish . [I]0-i soon saw also that there was more than girlish — a somewhat infantine expression in [her]347-a lady by no means small features ; this lisp and expression were , [I]0-i have no doubt , a charm in [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth ’s eyes , and would be so to those of [most men]351-most men , but they were not to [mine]0-i . [I]0-i sought [her]347-a lady eye , desirous to read there the intelligence which [I]0-i could not discern in [her]347-a lady face or hear in [her]347-a lady conversation ; it was merry , rather small ; by turns [I]0-i saw vivacity , vanity , coquetry , look out through its irid , but [I]0-i watched in vain for a glimpse of soul . [I]0-i am [no Oriental]352-no oriental ; white necks , carmine lips and cheeks , clusters of bright curls , do not suffice for [me]0-i without that Promethean spark which will live after the roses and lilies are faded , the burnished hair grown grey . In sunshine , in prosperity , the flowers are very well ; but how many wet days are there in life — November seasons of disaster , when [a man]353-a man ’s hearth and [home]1905-home would be cold indeed , without the clear , cheering gleam of intellect . “ Having perused the fair page of [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward ’s face , a deep , involuntary sigh announced [my]0-i disappointment ; [she]347-a lady took it as a homage to [her]347-a lady beauty , and [Edward]96-edward , who was evidently proud of [[his]357-mr. rich and handsome young wife]1927-his rich and handsome young wife , threw on [me]0-i a glance — half ridicule , half ire . “[0-i] [I]0-i turned from [them]355-them both , and gazing wearily round [the room]1922-the room , [I]0-i saw two pictures set in the oak panelling — one on each side the mantel - piece . Ceasing to take part in the bantering conversation that flowed on between [Mr.]357-mr. and [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward , [I]0-i bent [my]0-i thoughts to the examination of these pictures . They were portraits — [a lady]347-a lady and [a gentleman]359-a gentleman , both costumed in the fashion of twenty years ago . [The gentleman]360-the gentleman was in the shade . [I]0-i could not see [him]360-the gentleman well . [The lady]361-the lady had the benefit of a full beam from the softly shaded lamp . [I]0-i presently recognised [her]361-the lady ; [I]0-i had seen this picture before in childhood ; it was [[my]0-i mother]1887-my mother ; that and the companion picture being the only heir - looms saved out of the sale of [[[my]0-i father]298-my father ’s property]364-my father ’s property . “ The face , [I]0-i remembered , had pleased [me]0-i as [a boy]1928-a boy , but then [I]0-i did not understand it ; now [I]0-i knew how rare that class of face is in [the world]1872-the world , and [I]0-i appreciated keenly its thoughtful , yet gentle expression . The serious grey eye possessed for [me]0-i a strong charm , as did certain lines in the features indicative of most true and tender feeling . [I]0-i was sorry it was only a picture . “[0-i] [I]0-i soon left [Mr.]365-mr. and [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward to [themselves]366-themselves ; [a servant]367-a servant conducted [me]0-i to [[my]0-i bed - room]368-my bed - room ; in closing [[my]0-i chamber]369-my chamber - door , [I]0-i shut out [all intruders]370-all intruders — [you]371-you , [Charles]91-dear charles , as well as the rest . “ Good - bye for the present , “[103-william] [WILLIAM CRIMSWORTH]103-william . ” To this letter [I]103-william never got an answer ; before [[my]103-william old friend]1930-my old friend received it , [he]1930-my old friend had accepted a Government appointment in [one of]1931-one of [the colonies]1932-the colonies , and was already on [his]1930-my old friend way to the scene of [his]1930-my old friend official labours . What has become of [him]1930-my old friend since , [I]103-william know not . The leisure time [I]103-william have at command , and which [I]103-william intended to employ for [his]1930-my old friend private benefit , [I]103-william shall now dedicate to that of [the public at large]1933-the public at large . [My]103-william narrative is not exciting , and above all , not marvellous ; but it may interest [some individuals , who , having toiled in the same vocation as [myself]103-william]1934-some individuals , who , having toiled in the same vocation as myself , will find in [my]103-william experience frequent reflections of [their]1934-some individuals , who , having toiled in the same vocation as myself own . The above letter will serve as an introduction . [I]103-william now proceed . A FINE October morning succeeded to the foggy evening that had witnessed [my]103-william first introduction to [Crimsworth Hall]6-crimsworth hall . [I]103-william was early up and walking in [the large park - like meadow surrounding [the house]1897-the house]1935-the large park - like meadow surrounding the house . The autumn sun , rising over [the — — shire hills]1937-the — — shire hills , disclosed [a pleasant country]1938-a pleasant country ; woods brown and mellow varied the fields from which the harvest had been lately carried ; [a river , gliding between [the woods]1940-the woods]1939-a river , gliding between the woods , caught on its surface the somewhat cold gleam of the October sun and sky ; at frequent intervals along the banks of [the river]1941-the river , tall , cylindrical chimneys , almost like slender round towers , indicated [the factories which the trees half concealed]1942-the factories which the trees half concealed ; here and there [mansions]1943-mansions , similar to [Crimsworth Hall]6-crimsworth hall , occupied agreeable sites on [the hill - side]1944-the hill - side ; [the country]334-the country wore , on the whole , a cheerful , active , fertile look . Steam , trade , machinery had long banished from it all romance and seclusion . At a distance of five miles , [a valley]1946-a valley , opening between [the low hills]1947-the low hills , held in [its]1946-a valley cups [the great town of [X——.]8-x——.]1948-the great town of x——. A dense , permanent vapour brooded over [this locality]1949-this locality — there lay [Edward]96-edward ’s “[103-william] Concern . ” [I]103-william forced [my]103-william eye to scrutinize this prospect , [I]103-william forced [my]103-william mind to dwell on it for a time , and when [I]103-william found that it communicated no pleasurable emotion to [my]103-william heart — that it stirred in [me]103-william none of the hopes [a man]353-a man ought to feel , when [he]353-a man sees laid before [him]353-a man the scene of [his]353-a man life ’s career — [I]103-william said to [myself]103-william , “[103-william] [William]103-william , [you]103-william are [a rebel against circumstances]372-a rebel against circumstances ; [you]103-william are [a fool]304-a fool , and know not what [you]103-william want ; [you]103-william have chosen trade and [you]103-william shall be [a tradesman]302-a tradesman . Look ! ” [I]372-a rebel against circumstances continued mentally—“Look[372-a rebel against circumstances] at the sooty smoke in [that hollow]375-that hollow , and know that there is [your]103-william post ! There [you]103-william can not dream , [you]103-william can not speculate and theorize — there [you]103-william shall out and work ! ” Thus self - schooled , [I]372-a rebel against circumstances returned to [the house]1897-the house . [[My]372-a rebel against circumstances brother]1895-my brother was in [the breakfast - room]1953-the breakfast - room . [I]372-a rebel against circumstances met [him]1895-my brother collectedly — [I]372-a rebel against circumstances could not meet [him]1895-my brother cheerfully ; [he]1895-my brother was standing on the rug , [his]1895-my brother back to the fire — how much did [I]372-a rebel against circumstances read in the expression of [his]1895-my brother eye as [my]372-a rebel against circumstances glance encountered [his]1895-my brother , when [I]372-a rebel against circumstances advanced to bid [him]1895-my brother good morning ; how much that was contradictory to [my]372-a rebel against circumstances nature ! [He]1895-my brother said “[372-a rebel against circumstances] Good morning ” abruptly and nodded , and then [he]1895-my brother snatched , rather than took , a newspaper from the table , and began to read it with the air of [a master who seizes a pretext to escape the bore of conversing with [an underling]1955-an underling]1954-a master who seizes a pretext to escape the bore of conversing with an underling . It was well [I]105-steighton had taken a resolution to endure for a time , or [his]1895-my brother manner would have gone far to render insupportable the disgust [I]105-steighton had just been endeavouring to subdue . [I]105-steighton looked at [him]1895-my brother : [I]105-steighton measured [his]1895-my brother robust frame and powerful proportions ; [I]105-steighton saw [my]105-steighton own reflection in the mirror over the mantel - piece ; [I]105-steighton amused [myself]105-steighton with comparing the two pictures . In face [I]105-steighton resembled [him]1895-my brother , though [I]105-steighton was not so handsome ; [my]105-steighton features were less regular ; [I]105-steighton had a darker eye , and a broader brow — in form [I]105-steighton was greatly inferior — thinner , slighter , not so tall . As an animal , [Edward]96-edward excelled [me]105-steighton far ; should [he]1895-my brother prove as paramount in mind as in [person]1956-person [I]105-steighton must be [a slave]1957-a slave — for [I]105-steighton must expect from [him]1895-my brother no lion - like generosity to one weaker than [himself]1895-my brother ; [his]1895-my brother cold , avaricious eye , [his]1895-my brother stern , forbidding manner told [me]105-steighton [he]1895-my brother would not spare . Had [I]105-steighton then force of mind to cope with [him]1895-my brother ? [I]105-steighton did not know ; [I]105-steighton had never been tried . [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward ’s entrance diverted [my]105-steighton thoughts for a moment . [She]96-edward looked well , dressed in white , [her]96-edward face and [her]96-edward attire shining in morning and bridal freshness . [I]105-steighton addressed [her]96-edward with the degree of ease [her]96-edward last night ’s careless gaiety seemed to warrant , but [she]96-edward replied with coolness and restraint : [[her]96-edward husband]1958-her husband had tutored [her]96-edward ; [she]96-edward was not to be too familiar with [[his]1958-her husband clerk]1959-his clerk . As soon as breakfast was over [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth intimated to [me]105-steighton that [they]1960-they were bringing the gig round to the door , and that in five minutes [he]99-mr. crimsworth should expect [me]105-steighton to be ready to go down with [him]99-mr. crimsworth to X——. [I]105-steighton did not keep [him]99-mr. crimsworth waiting ; [we]1961-we were soon dashing at a rapid rate along [the road]1962-the road . The horse [he]99-mr. crimsworth drove was the same vicious animal about which [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward had expressed [her]96-edward fears the night before . Once or twice [Jack]102-jack seemed disposed to turn restive , but a vigorous and determined application of the whip from the ruthless hand of [[his]102-jack master]1904-his master soon compelled [him]102-jack to submission , and [Edward]96-edward ’s dilated nostril expressed [his]102-jack triumph in the result of the contest ; [he]102-jack scarcely spoke to [me]105-steighton during the whole of the brief drive , only opening [his]102-jack lips at intervals to damn [his]102-jack horse . [X]7-x — — was all stir and bustle when [we]1961-we entered [it]7-x ; [we]1961-we left [the clean streets]1964-the clean streets where there were [dwelling - houses]1965-dwelling - houses and [shops]1966-shops , [churches]1967-churches , and [public buildings]1968-public buildings ; [we]1961-we left all these , and turned down to [a region of [mills]1970-mills and [warehouses]1971-warehouses]1969-a region of mills and warehouses ; thence [we]1961-we passed through two massive gates into [a great paved yard]1972-a great paved yard , and [we]1961-we were in [Bigben Close]5-bigben close , and [the mill]1973-the mill was before [us]1961-we , vomiting soot from [its]1973-the mill long chimney , and quivering through [its]1973-the mill thick brick walls with the commotion of its iron bowels . [Workpeople]1974-workpeople were passing to and fro ; a waggon was being laden with pieces . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth looked from side to side , and seemed at one glance to comprehend all that was going on ; [he]99-mr. crimsworth alighted , and leaving [his]99-mr. crimsworth horse and gig to the care of [a man who hastened to take the reins from [his]99-mr. crimsworth hand]1975-a man who hastened to take the reins from his hand , [he]99-mr. crimsworth bid [me]105-steighton follow [him]99-mr. crimsworth to [the counting - house]1913-the counting - house . [We]1961-we entered [it]1913-the counting - house ; [a very different place from [the parlours of [Crimsworth Hall]6-crimsworth hall]1978-the parlours of crimsworth hall]1977-a very different place from the parlours of crimsworth hall — [a place for business]1979-a place for business , with a bare , planked floor , a safe , two high desks and stools , and some chairs . [A person]1980-a person was seated at one of the desks , who took off [his]1980-a person square cap when [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth entered , and in an instant was again absorbed in [his]99-mr. crimsworth occupation of writing or calculating — [I]105-steighton know not which . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , having removed [his]99-mr. crimsworth mackintosh , sat down by the fire . [I]105-steighton remained standing near the hearth ; [he]99-mr. crimsworth said presently — “[105-steighton] [Steighton]105-steighton , [you]105-steighton may leave [the room]1922-the room ; [I]0-i have some business to transact with [this gentleman]377-this gentleman . Come back when [you]105-steighton hear the bell . ” [The individual at the desk]1981-the individual at the desk rose and departed , closing the door as [he]99-mr. crimsworth went out . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth stirred the fire , then folded [his]99-mr. crimsworth arms , and sat a moment thinking , [his]99-mr. crimsworth lips compressed , [his]99-mr. crimsworth brow knit . [I]105-steighton had nothing to do but to watch [him]99-mr. crimsworth — how well [his]99-mr. crimsworth features were cut ! what [a handsome man]1982-a handsome man [he]99-mr. crimsworth was ! Whence , then , came that air of contraction — that narrow and hard aspect on [his]99-mr. crimsworth forehead , in all [his]99-mr. crimsworth lineaments ? Turning to [me]105-steighton [he]99-mr. crimsworth began abruptly : “[105-steighton] [You]105-steighton are come down to — — shire to learn to be [a tradesman]302-a tradesman ? ” “[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i am . ” “[0-i] Have [you]105-steighton made up [your]105-steighton mind on the point ? Let [me]0-i know that at once . ” “[0-i] Yes . ” “[0-i] Well , [I]0-i am not bound to help [you]105-steighton , but [I]0-i have [a place [here vacant]380-here vacant , if [you]105-steighton are qualified for it]379-a place here vacant , if you are qualified for it . [I]0-i will take [you]105-steighton on trial . What can [you]105-steighton do ? Do [you]105-steighton know anything besides that useless trash of college learning — Greek , Latin , and so forth ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have studied mathematics . ” “[0-i] Stuff ! [I]0-i dare say [you]105-steighton have . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i can read and write French and German . ” “[0-i] Hum ! ” [He]105-steighton reflected a moment , then opening a drawer in a desk near [him]105-steighton took out a letter , and gave it to [me]0-i . “[0-i] Can [you]105-steighton read that ? ” [he]105-steighton asked . It was a German commercial letter ; [I]105-steighton translated it ; [I]105-steighton could not tell whether [he]105-steighton was gratified or not — [his]105-steighton countenance remained fixed . “[105-steighton] It is well , ” [he]105-steighton said , after a pause , “[105-steighton] that [you]105-steighton are acquainted with something useful , something that may enable [you]105-steighton to earn [your]105-steighton board and lodging : since [you]105-steighton know French and German , [I]0-i will take [you]105-steighton as [second clerk]381-second clerk to manage the foreign correspondence of [the house]1897-the house . [I]0-i shall give [you]105-steighton a good salary—90l . a year — and now , ” [he]105-steighton continued , raising [his]105-steighton voice , “[0-i] hear once for all what [I]0-i have to say about [our]383-our relationship , and all that sort of humbug ! [I]0-i must have no nonsense on that point ; it would never suit [me]0-i . [I]0-i shall excuse [you]105-steighton nothing on the plea of being [[my]0-i brother]1895-my brother ; if [I]0-i find [you]105-steighton stupid , negligent , dissipated , idle , or possessed of any faults detrimental to the interests of [the house]1897-the house , [I]0-i shall dismiss [you]105-steighton as [I]0-i would [any other clerk]386-any other clerk . Ninety pounds a year are good wages , and [I]0-i expect to have the full value of [my]0-i money out of [you]105-steighton ; remember , too , that things are on a practical footing in [my]0-i establishment — business - like habits , feelings , and ideas , suit [me]0-i best . Do [you]105-steighton understand ? ” “[105-steighton] Partly , ” [I]105-steighton replied . “[105-steighton] [I]0-i suppose [you]105-steighton mean that [I]0-i am to do [my]0-i work for [my]0-i wages ; not to expect favour from [you]105-steighton , and not to depend on [you]105-steighton for any help but what [I]0-i earn ; that suits [me]0-i exactly , and on these terms [I]0-i will consent to be [[your]105-steighton clerk]387-your clerk . ” [I]105-steighton turned on [my]105-steighton heel , and walked to the window ; this time [I]105-steighton did not consult [his]105-steighton face to learn [his]105-steighton opinion : what it was [I]105-steighton do not know , nor did [I]105-steighton then care . After a silence of some minutes [he]105-steighton recommenced : — “[105-steighton] [You]105-steighton perhaps expect to be accommodated with [apartments]388-apartments at [Crimsworth Hall]6-crimsworth hall , and to go and come with [me]0-i in [the gig]389-the gig . [I]0-i wish [you]105-steighton , however , to be aware that such an arrangement would be quite inconvenient to [me]0-i . [I]0-i like to have the seat in [my]0-i gig at liberty for [any gentleman whom for business reasons [I]0-i may wish to take down to [the hall]1910-the hall for a night or so]390-any gentleman whom for business reasons i may wish to take down to the hall for a night or so . [You]105-steighton will seek out lodgings in X——. ” Quitting the window , [I]0-i walked back to the hearth . “[0-i] Of course [I]0-i shall seek out lodgings in X — — , ” [I]0-i answered . “[0-i] It would not suit [me]0-i either to lodge at [Crimsworth Hall]6-crimsworth hall . ” [My]0-i tone was quiet . [I]0-i always speak quietly . Yet [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth ’s blue eye became incensed ; [he]99-mr. crimsworth took [his]99-mr. crimsworth revenge rather oddly . Turning to [me]0-i [he]99-mr. crimsworth said bluntly — “[0-i] [You]105-steighton are poor enough , [I]0-i suppose ; how do [you]105-steighton expect to live till [your]105-steighton quarter ’s salary becomes due ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i shall get on , ” said [I.]0-i “[0-i] How do [you]105-steighton expect to live ? ” [he]99-mr. crimsworth repeated in a louder voice . “[0-i] As [I]0-i can , [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth . ” “[99-mr. crimsworth] Get into debt at [your]105-steighton peril ! that ’s all , ” [he]99-mr. crimsworth answered . “[0-i] For aught [I]0-i know [you]105-steighton may have extravagant aristocratic habits : if [you]105-steighton have , drop them ; [I]0-i tolerate nothing of the sort here , and [I]0-i will never give [you]105-steighton a shilling extra , whatever liabilities [you]105-steighton may incur — mind that . ” “[99-mr. crimsworth] Yes , [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , [you]99-mr. crimsworth will find [I]0-i have a good memory . ” [I]0-i said no more . [I]0-i did not think the time was come for much parley . [I]0-i had an instinctive feeling that it would be folly to let [one]1983-one ’s temper effervesce often with [such a man as [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth]1984-such a man as edward . [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i , “[0-i] [I]0-i will place [my]0-i cup under this continual dropping ; it shall stand there still and steady ; when full , it will run over of itself — meantime patience . Two things are certain . [I]0-i am capable of performing the work [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth has set [me]0-i ; [I]0-i can earn [my]0-i wages conscientiously , and those wages are sufficient to enable [me]0-i to live . As to the fact of [[my]0-i brother]1895-my brother assuming towards [me]0-i the bearing of [a proud , harsh master]393-a proud , harsh master , the fault is [his]1895-my brother , not [mine]0-i ; and shall [his]1895-my brother injustice , [his]1895-my brother bad feeling , turn [me]0-i at once aside from the path [I]0-i have chosen ? No ; at least , ere [I]0-i deviate , [I]0-i will advance far enough to see whither [my]0-i career tends . As yet [I]0-i am only pressing in at the entrance — a strait gate enough ; it ought to have a good terminus . ” While [I]105-steighton thus reasoned , [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth rang a bell ; [[his]99-mr. crimsworth first clerk]1985-his first clerk , [the individual dismissed previously to [our]1987-our conference]1986-the individual dismissed previously to our conference , re - entered . “[105-steighton] [Mr. Steighton]105-steighton , ” said [he]105-steighton , “[105-steighton] show [Mr. William]101-william the letters from [Voss]106-voss , [Brothers]394-brothers , and give [him]101-william English copies of the answers ; [he]101-william will translate them . ” [Mr. Steighton]105-steighton , [a man of about thirty - five , with a face at once sly and heavy]1988-a man of about thirty - five , with a face at once sly and heavy , hastened to execute this order ; [he]105-steighton laid the letters on the desk , and [I]105-steighton was soon seated at it , and engaged in rendering the English answers into German . A sentiment of keen pleasure accompanied this first effort to earn [my]105-steighton own living — a sentiment neither poisoned nor weakened by the presence of [the taskmaster]1989-the taskmaster , who stood and watched [me]105-steighton for some time as [I]105-steighton wrote . [I]105-steighton thought [he]1989-the taskmaster was trying to read [my]105-steighton character , but [I]105-steighton felt as secure against [his]1989-the taskmaster scrutiny as if [I]105-steighton had had on a casque with the visor down — or rather [I]105-steighton showed [him]1989-the taskmaster [my]105-steighton countenance with the confidence that one would show [an unlearned man]1990-an unlearned man a letter written in Greek ; [he]1989-the taskmaster might see lines , and trace characters , but [he]1989-the taskmaster could make nothing of them ; [my]105-steighton nature was not [his]1989-the taskmaster nature , and its signs were to [him]1989-the taskmaster like the words of an unknown tongue . Ere long [he]1989-the taskmaster turned away abruptly , as if baffled , and left [the counting - house]1913-the counting - house ; [he]1989-the taskmaster returned to [it]1913-the counting - house but twice in the course of that day ; each time [he]1989-the taskmaster mixed and swallowed a glass of brandy - and - water , the materials for making which [he]1989-the taskmaster extracted from a cupboard on one side of the fireplace ; having glanced at [my]105-steighton translations — [he]1989-the taskmaster could read both French and German — [he]1989-the taskmaster went out again in silence . [I]105-steighton SERVED [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth as [[his]99-mr. crimsworth second clerk]1992-his second clerk faithfully , punctually , diligently . What was given [me]105-steighton to do [I]105-steighton had the power and the determination to do well . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth watched sharply for defects , but found none ; [he]99-mr. crimsworth set [Timothy Steighton]107-tim , [[his]99-mr. crimsworth favourite and head man]1993-his favourite and head man , to watch also . [Tim]107-tim was baffled ; [I]105-steighton was as exact as [himself]107-tim , and quicker . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth made inquiries as to how [I]105-steighton lived , whether [I]105-steighton got into debt — no , [my]105-steighton accounts with [[my]105-steighton landlady]1994-my landlady were always straight . [I]105-steighton had hired [small lodgings , which [I]105-steighton contrived to pay for out of a slender fund]1995-small lodgings , which i contrived to pay for out of a slender fund — the accumulated savings of [my]105-steighton Eton pocket - money ; for as it had ever been abhorrent to [my]105-steighton nature to ask pecuniary assistance , [I]105-steighton had early acquired habits of self - denying economy ; husbanding [my]105-steighton monthly allowance with anxious care , in order to obviate the danger of being forced , in some moment of future exigency , to beg additional aid . [I]105-steighton remember [many]1996-many called [me]105-steighton miser at the time , and [I]105-steighton used to couple the reproach with this consolation — better to be misunderstood now than repulsed hereafter . At this day [I]105-steighton had [my]105-steighton reward ; [I]105-steighton had had it before , when on parting with [[my]105-steighton irritated]1997-my irritated uncles one of [them]1997-my irritated threw down on the table before [me]105-steighton a 5l . note , which [I]105-steighton was able to leave [there]1998-there , saying that [my]105-steighton travelling expenses were already provided for . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth employed [Tim]107-tim to find out whether [[my]105-steighton landlady]1994-my landlady had any complaint to make on the score of [my]105-steighton morals ; [she]1994-my landlady answered that [she]1994-my landlady believed [I]105-steighton was [a very religious man]2000-a very religious man , and asked [Tim]107-tim , in [her]1994-my landlady turn , if [he]107-tim thought [I]105-steighton had any intention of going into [the Church]286-the church some day ; for , [she]1994-my landlady said , [she]1994-my landlady had had [young curates]2002-young curates to lodge in [[her]1994-my landlady house]2003-her house who were nothing equal to [me]105-steighton for steadiness and quietness . [Tim]107-tim was “[2004-a religious man ”] [a religious man ”]2004-a religious man ” [himself]107-tim ; indeed , [he]107-tim was “[105-steighton] [a joined Methodist , ”]2005-a joined methodist , ” which did not ( be it understood ) prevent [him]107-tim from being at the same time [an engrained rascal]2006-an engrained rascal , and [he]107-tim came away much posed at hearing this account of [my]2005-a joined methodist , ” piety . Having imparted it to [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , [that gentleman]315-that gentleman , who [himself]99-mr. crimsworth frequented [no place of worship]2008-no place of worship , and owned no God but [Mammon]108-mammon , turned the information into a weapon of attack against the equability of [my]2005-a joined methodist , ” temper . [He]99-mr. crimsworth commenced a series of covert sneers , of which [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” did not at first perceive the drift , till [[my]2005-a joined methodist , ” landlady]1994-my landlady happened to relate the conversation [she]1994-my landlady had had with [Mr. Steighton]105-steighton ; this enlightened [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” ; afterwards [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” came to [the counting - house]1913-the counting - house prepared , and managed to receive [the millowner]2011-the millowner ’s blasphemous sarcasms , when next levelled at [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” , on a buckler of impenetrable indifference . Ere long [he]99-mr. crimsworth tired of wasting [his]99-mr. crimsworth ammunition on a statue , but [he]99-mr. crimsworth did not throw away the shafts — [he]99-mr. crimsworth only kept them quiet in [his]99-mr. crimsworth quiver . Once during [my]2005-a joined methodist , ” clerkship [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” had an invitation to [Crimsworth Hall]6-crimsworth hall ; it was on the occasion of a large party given in honour of [the master]2012-the master ’s birthday ; [he]99-mr. crimsworth had always been accustomed to invite [[his]99-mr. crimsworth clerks]2013-his clerks on similar anniversaries , and could not well pass [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” over ; [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” was , however , kept strictly in the background . [Mrs. Crimsworth]96-edward , elegantly dressed in satin and lace , blooming in youth and health , vouchsafed [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” no more notice than was expressed by a distant move ; [Crimsworth]96-edward , of course , never spoke to [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” ; [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” was introduced to [none of the band of young ladies]2014-none of the band of young ladies , who , enveloped in silvery clouds of white gauze and muslin , sat in array against [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” on the opposite side of [a long and large room]2015-a long and large room ; in fact , [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” was fairly isolated , and could but contemplate [the shining ones from afar]2016-the shining ones from afar , and when weary of such a dazzling scene , turn for a change to the consideration of the carpet pattern . [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , standing on the rug , [his]99-mr. crimsworth elbow supported by the marble mantelpiece , and about [him]99-mr. crimsworth a group of very pretty girls , with whom [he]99-mr. crimsworth conversed gaily — [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , thus placed , glanced at [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” ; [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” looked weary , solitary , kept down like [some desolate tutor]2017-some desolate tutor or [governess]2018-governess ; [he]99-mr. crimsworth was satisfied . Dancing began ; [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” should have liked well enough to be introduced to [some pleasing and intelligent girl]2019-some pleasing and intelligent girl , and to have freedom and opportunity to show that [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” could both feel and communicate the pleasure of social intercourse — that [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” was not , in short , a block , or a piece of furniture , but [an acting , thinking , sentient man]2020-an acting , thinking , sentient man . [Many smiling faces and graceful figures]2021-many smiling faces and graceful figures glided past [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” , but the smiles were lavished on other eyes , the figures sustained by other hands than [mine]2005-a joined methodist , ” . [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” turned away tantalized , left [the dancers]2022-the dancers , and wandered into [the oak - panelled dining - room]2023-the oak - panelled dining - room . No fibre of sympathy united [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” to any living thing in [this house]2024-this house ; [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” looked for and found [[my]2005-a joined methodist , ” mother]1887-my mother ’s picture . [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” took a wax taper from a stand , and held it up . [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” gazed long , earnestly ; [my]2005-a joined methodist , ” heart grew to the image . [[My]2005-a joined methodist , ” mother]1887-my mother , [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” perceived , had bequeathed to [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” much of [her]1887-my mother features and countenance — [her]1887-my mother forehead , [her]1887-my mother eyes , [her]1887-my mother complexion . No regular beauty pleases [egotistical human beings]2027-egotistical human beings so much as a softened and refined likeness of [themselves]2027-egotistical human beings ; for this reason , [fathers]2028-fathers regard with complacency the lineaments of [[their]2028-fathers daughters]2029-their daughters ’ faces , where frequently [their]2029-their daughters own similitude is found flatteringly associated with softness of hue and delicacy of outline . [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” was just wondering how that picture , to [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” so interesting , would strike [an impartial spectator]2030-an impartial spectator , when a voice close behind [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” pronounced the words — “[2005-a joined methodist , ”] Humph ! there ’s some sense in that face . ” [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” turned ; at [my]2005-a joined methodist , ” elbow stood [a tall man]2031-a tall man , young , though probably five or six years older than [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” — in other respects of an appearance the opposite to common place ; though just now , as [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” am not disposed to paint [his]2031-a tall man portrait in detail , [the reader]2032-the reader must be content with the silhouette [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” have just thrown off ; it was all [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” [myself]2005-a joined methodist , ” saw of [him]2031-a tall man for the moment : [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” did not investigate the colour of [his]2031-a tall man eyebrows , nor of [his]2031-a tall man eyes either ; [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” saw [his]2031-a tall man stature , and the outline of [his]2031-a tall man shape ; [I]2005-a joined methodist , ” saw , too , [his]2031-a tall man fastidious - looking retroussé nose ; these observations , few in number , and general in character ( the last excepted ) , sufficed , for they enabled [me]2005-a joined methodist , ” to recognize [him]2031-a tall man . “[2005-a joined methodist , ”] Good evening , [Mr. Hunsden]109-hunsden , ” muttered [I]109-hunsden with a bow , and then , like a shy noodle as [I]109-hunsden was , [I]109-hunsden began moving away — and why ? Simply because [Mr. Hunsden]109-hunsden was [a manufacturer]2033-a manufacturer and [a millowner]2034-a millowner , and [I]109-hunsden was only [a clerk]2035-a clerk , and [my]109-hunsden instinct propelled [me]109-hunsden from [[my]109-hunsden superior]2036-my superior . [I]109-hunsden had frequently seen [Hunsden]109-hunsden in [Bigben Close]5-bigben close , where [he]109-hunsden came almost weekly to transact business with [Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , but [I]109-hunsden had never spoken to [him]109-hunsden , nor [he]109-hunsden to [me]109-hunsden , and [I]109-hunsden owed [him]109-hunsden a sort of involuntary grudge , because [he]109-hunsden had more than once been the tacit witness of insults offered by [Edward]99-mr. crimsworth to [me]109-hunsden . [I]109-hunsden had the conviction that [he]109-hunsden could only regard [me]109-hunsden as a poor - spirited slave , wherefore [I]109-hunsden now went about to shun [his]109-hunsden presence and eschew [his]109-hunsden conversation . “[109-hunsden] Where are [you]395-you going ? ” asked [he]109-hunsden , as [I]396-i edged off sideways . [I]396-i had already noticed that [Mr. Hunsden]109-hunsden indulged in abrupt forms of speech , and [I]396-i perversely said to [myself]396-i — “[396-i] [He]396-i thinks [he]396-i may speak as [he]396-i likes to [a poor clerk]397-a poor clerk ; but [my]0-i mood is not , perhaps , so supple as [he]396-i deems it , and [his]396-i rough freedom pleases [me]0-i not at all . ” [I]396-i made some slight reply , rather indifferent than courteous , and continued to move away . [He]109-hunsden coolly planted [himself]109-hunsden in [my]396-i path . “[396-i] Stay [here]398-here awhile , ” said [he]109-hunsden : “[396-i] it is so hot in [the dancing - room]399-the dancing - room ; besides , [you]0-i do n’t dance ; [you]0-i have not had [a partner]400-a partner to - night . ” [He]109-hunsden was right , and as [he]109-hunsden spoke neither [his]109-hunsden look , tone , nor manner displeased [me]401-you ; [my]401-you amour - propre was propitiated ; [he]109-hunsden had not addressed [me]401-you out of condescension , but because , having repaired to [the cool dining - room]2037-the cool dining - room for refreshment , [he]109-hunsden now wanted [some one]2038-some one to talk to , by way of temporary amusement . [I]401-you hate to be condescended to , but [I]401-you like well enough to oblige ; [I]401-you stayed . “[401-you] That is a good picture , ” [he]109-hunsden continued , recurring to the portrait . “[401-you] Do [you]401-you consider the face pretty ? ” [I]401-you asked . “[401-you] Pretty ! no — how can it be pretty , with sunk eyes and hollow cheeks ? but it is peculiar ; it seems to think . [You]0-i could have a talk with [that woman]402-that woman , if [she]402-that woman were alive , on other subjects than dress , visiting , and compliments . ” [I]0-i agreed with [him]109-hunsden , but did not say so . [He]109-hunsden went on . “[0-i] Not that [I]0-i admire a head of that sort ; it wants character and force ; there ’s too much of the sen - si - tive ( so [he]401-you articulated it , curling [his]401-you lip at the same time ) in that mouth ; besides , there is [Aristocrat written on the brow and defined in the figure]403-aristocrat written on the brow and defined in the figure ; [I]0-i hate [[your]401-you aristocrats]404-your aristocrats . ” “[401-you] [You]401-you think , then , [Mr. Hunsden]109-hunsden , that patrician descent may be read in a distinctive cast of form and features ? ” “[401-you] Patrician descent be hanged ! Who doubts that [[your]401-you lordlings]405-your lordlings may have [their]405-your lordlings ‘ distinctive cast of form and features ’ as much as [we]406-we —— [shire tradesmen]407-shire tradesmen have [ours]406-we ? But which is the best ? Not [theirs]405-your lordlings assuredly . As to [[their]405-your lordlings women]408-their women , it is a little different : [they]408-their women cultivate beauty from childhood upwards , and may by care and training attain to a certain degree of excellence in that point , just like the oriental odalisques . Yet even this superiority is doubtful . Compare the figure in that frame with [Mrs. Edward Crimsworth]96-edward — which is the finer animal ? ” [I]96-edward replied quietly : “[96-edward] Compare [yourself]401-you and [Mr. Edward Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , [Mr Hunsden]109-hunsden . ” “[109-hunsden] Oh , [Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth is better filled up than [I]0-i am , [I]0-i know besides [he]99-mr. crimsworth has a straight nose , arched eyebrows , and all that ; but these advantages — if they are advantages — [he]99-mr. crimsworth did not inherit from [[his]99-mr. crimsworth mother]409-his mother , [the patrician]410-the patrician , but from [[his]99-mr. crimsworth father]411-his father , [old Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth , who , [[my]0-i father]298-my father says , was as veritable a — — [shire blue - dyer as ever put indigo]413-shire blue - dyer as ever put indigo in a vat yet withal [the handsomest man in the three Ridings]414-the handsomest man in the three ridings . It is [you]401-you , [William]101-william , who are [the aristocrat of [[your]401-you family]416-your family , and [you]401-you are not as fine a fellow as [[your]401-you plebeian brother]417-your plebeian brother by long chalk]415-the aristocrat of your family , and you are not as fine a fellow as your plebeian brother by long chalk . ” There was something in [Mr. Hunsden]109-hunsden ’s point - blank mode of speech which rather pleased [me]401-you than otherwise because it set [me]401-you at [my]401-you ease . [I]401-you continued the conversation with a degree of interest . “[401-you] How do [you]401-you happen to know that [I]0-i am [[Mr. Crimsworth]99-mr. crimsworth ’s brother]418-mr. crimsworth ’s brother ?
